results.title: For all practical purposes. On size and shape. 1
results.brief_description: Overview There is very often a direct and measurable relationship betweem maths and our concept of beauty, often based on geometry. This program explores this relationship, through spirals and the Fibonacci sequence, the golden ratio, the golden rectangle, perspective, symmetry, repeating patterns, hyperbolic geometry and fractal geometry. The works of Leonardo da Vinci and M. C. Escher, as well as natural forms are used to illustrate the relationship.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Management science. 5
results.brief_description: Juicy problems Using a simplified model of the production of two different types of fruit juice, this program shows how linear programming can solve production policy problems bearing in mind material constraints. Concepts of feasible points and sets, the corner principle and the simplex method are introduced along with the related algebraic formulae. The program concludes by showing how mathematical research is constantly seeking ways to improve linear programming methods.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Management science. 4
results.brief_description: Juggling machines looks at the problems of scheduling. Before looking at complex situations it is best to simplify the problem to get essentials which can then be applied to the more complex situations. This is done by reducing variables, making assumptions and adopting rules. The example used is getting news stories ready for airing within a fixed time-limit. The algorithms demonstrated are: first fit, list processing, first fit decreasing, performance bound and bin packing, of which the heuristic algorithms are quicker but not optimal.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Management science. 3
results.brief_description: Trains, planes and critical paths expands on the problems of the previous program, by looking at “The Travelling salesman problem”, i.e. the best route for including all the proposed stops with the lowest possible mileage. This problem can be applied to other circuits, such as telephone services, building construction and constructing a computer circuit, but all can be solved using algorithms and graphs, demonstrating yet again that practical problems are often best tackled with pure maths.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Management science. 2
results.brief_description: Street smarts demonstrates the Euler circuit, or the quickest, most efficient way around a circuit. Using the example of various street circuit functions, such as parking meter inspection, garbage collection and street sweeping the program demonstrates how a mathematical model such as a Euler circuit will help find the best route. Starting with a very simple diagram to demonstrate the technique, the program concludes by showing how computers can use the same techniques for very complex situations.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Management science. 1
results.brief_description: In this first program, “Overview”, Sol Garfunkel introduces the concept of optimisation, of ensuring that a particular project is completed in the best possible way, within the restraints of cost, performance and schedule. Using examples such as the Apollo moon shot and ensuring customer satisfaction at Disneyworld, the program introduces the mathematical concepts of scheduling, queuing, and critical path analysis and shows how the application of mathematics is vital to the management of any enterprise.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Computer science. 5
results.creator_credit: COMAP, Chedd-Angier Productions and Joseph Blatt
results.brief_description: Moving picture show Computers can be used to produce a remarkable range of graphics and this program looks at how these graphics are produced. Pixels are the fundamental unit of computer images, and nothing can be drawn smaller than a pixel, which means that lines can be jagged rather than smooth. We look at anti-aliasing techniques which solve this and algorithms which solve the problems of limited time and memory. We then look at three programs from Symbolics Inc. - “Geometry” which creates 3D objects, “Dynamics” which moves them and “Render” which makes them realistic. Demonstrated techniques include splining, translation, scaling, rotation, texture mapping and opacity.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Computer science. 4
results.creator_credit: COMAP, Chedd-Angier Productions and Lance Wisniewski
results.brief_description: Creating codes Developing the concept of binary codes, introduced in the previous episode, this program looks at some of the different codes which can be devised, including ASCII which is a 7 bit code, the Laplacian pyramid which is used for encoding pictorial images and the Hamming code, which enables computers to overcome random errors.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Computer science. 3
results.brief_description: Counting by twos Sol Garfunkel explains the binary system and how it enables computers to function. He demonstrates the system through the digital recording of music and player piano rolls and goes on to explain booleian logic.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Computer science. 2
results.brief_description: In this program Sol Garfunkel explains and defines algorithms, which are a sequence of steps or directions to accomplish a goal, and which lie at the root of programming. Algorithms must be well-defined, effective, must produce an output and must terminate in a reasonable period of time. Examples used to demonstrate are making a peanut butter and jam sandwich and finding the best route to work. The program concludes with a basic task of a computer - sorting and two forms of sorting - insertion sorting and merge sorting.
